title: Zero to IPO: Introduction to Biomedical Enterprises
description: This course provides an overview of the full life cycle of biomedical enterprises, from research idea to Initial Public Offering (IPO). Covering broad topics such as company incorporation, financial assessment, licensing, regulatory requirements, and development strategy, students will complete the course well-equipped with the core concepts necessary to work in biomedical business development, management, and venture capital roles.

title: Internship
description: The BEHM4000 Summer Internship Program is designed to provide Year 3 or above BEHM students with practical hands-on experience in the field of Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management. Through this internship, students will have the opportunity to integrate their knowledge and skills acquired in previous courses into real-world settings. They will develop problem-solving abilities, enhance teamwork skills, and gain valuable industry experience to support their career development.
outcome: By the end of the internship program, students are expected to: Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical skills acquired in previous courses into real-world scenarios. Design, organize, schedule, and execute individual or group projects related to Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management. Acquire hands-on techniques in conducting experiments or special projects provided by the internship provider. Develop effective problem-solving abilities in the context of the biotechnology, entrepreneurship, and healthcare management sectors. Work collaboratively with a team in a professional laboratory or company setting. Cultivate a sense of responsibility and professionalism in the workplace. Gain empirical experiences and out-of-classroom experiences to support career development in the field of Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management. Improve written communication skills through the preparation of comprehensive internship reports.

title: Capstone Project I
description: This course is part I of the capstone project in which students will conduct critical analyses of the existing business models and policies related to the biotechnology industry and healthcare system. It allows students to conduct independent studies related to biotechnology, entrepreneurship and healthcare management. Students will form groups to critically analyze selected companies or policies on healthcare and/or environmental sustainability so that they will be motivated by how these companies, policies, or management strategies are running and their significance in contributing to society. Students will apply knowledge and techniques learned from courses of the relevant concentration areas and conduct a deeper study into specific topics of their interests in biotechnology, entrepreneurship and/or healthcare management. Students and instructors will conduct progress meetings on a regular basis. Students are expected to give oral presentations and submit their reports at the end of the course.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: integrate and illustrate understanding: through learning how biotechnology, entrepreneurship and healthcare management intersect, illustrates activities and considerations essential to building a successful business or management strategy; conduct critical analysis: develop skills to evaluate biotech and healthcare models and policies; learn research and independent study skills: gain experience in independent research and data analysis; apply knowledge: to analyze business models or polices related to biotech, entrepreneurship, and healthcare management. discuss from an entrepreneurial perspective: foster innovation and growth by critically evaluating existing models and policies.

title: Capstone Project II
description: This course is part II of the capstone project which is a continuation of the analytical work undertaken by students in the BEHM4001 Capstone Project I, focusing on utilizing research findings to enhance business models and policies within the biotechnology and healthcare sectors. After critically evaluating the companies or policies investigated in Capstone Project I, students should ideate and design a prototype based on the recommendations they developed for optimizing these business practices, improving operational efficiency, and fostering sustainable development. Students are encouraged to test and improve their prototypes, establish their start-ups or NGOs wherever practicable to foster entrepreneurial skills, and provide them with practical experience in developing and implementing strategies, through applying their knowledge and skills acquired from the previous coursework and employing innovative thinking to address real-world challenges. Guidance will be provided by the instructor and regular consultations will ensure the alignment of project objectives. By the end of this course, students will present their proposals through comprehensive oral presentations and provide detailed portfolios, demonstrating their ability to apply theoretical concepts to practical scenarios and contribute meaningfully to biotechnology or healthcare management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: Make recommendations, ideation and produce prototypes: suggest practical recommendations to enhance practices and increase efficiency, actualize ideation through establishing and testing prototypes. Apply knowledge: through applying knowledge learned from previous courses to solve real-world challenges in biotechnology and healthcare. Effectively collaborate: work well in teams, demonstrating good communication and collaboration skills. Think creatively: use innovative thinking to propose solutions that support sustainability and benefit society. Present ideas clearly: share findings through professional oral presentations and portfolios. Reflect on experience: reflect on personal contributions and the learning process to support continuous improvement. Establish new business: gain practical experience in developing and implementing business strategies.
